etymology.description: ideogrammic: 禾 + 口 (bag/rope) + 刀; later stylized as 柬 + 刀; originally ‘to cut cereal plants, to harvest’.
etymology.interpretation: Early forms depict grain with a bag or cord and a knife, indicating cutting and gathering the crop at harvest. In bronze script it was stylized as a stuffed bag (柬) plus a knife, and the sense broadened over time to actions like slashing or pricking.

examples.chinese: 收割时，他们用刀剌断稻秆(收割時，他們用刀剌斷稻稈)。
examples.pinyin: Shōugē shí, tāmen yòng dāo là duàn dàogǎn.
examples.english: During harvest, they used a knife to cut through the rice stalks.

examples.chinese: 小心玫瑰的枝上有许多剌，会剌到你的手(小心玫瑰的枝上有許多剌，會剌到你的手)。
examples.pinyin: Xiǎoxīn méiguī de zhī shàng yǒu xǔduō là, huì là dào nǐ de shǒu.
examples.english: Be careful, there are many thorns on the rose branches; they can prick your hand.

examples.chinese: 他在布上剌了一道口子(他在布上剌了一道口子)。
examples.pinyin: Tā zài bù shàng là le yī dào kǒuzi.
examples.english: He slashed the cloth, leaving a cut.
